facts: The first practical gasoline-powered cars were built in the late 1800s, and they quickly changed how people traveled long distances.
A carâ€™s engine turns fuel into motion by making controlled explosions that push pistons up and down inside metal cylinders.
Most modern cars use a radiator and coolant to carry away extra heat so the engine does not overheat.
Trucks can carry heavier loads than cars because they often have stronger frames, stiffer suspension, and more powerful brakes.
Some large trucks use diesel fuel because diesel engines can produce strong pulling power and often get better fuel efficiency for heavy work.
Seat belts and airbags work together, with seat belts holding you in place while airbags cushion your head and chest during a crash.
Electric cars use batteries and electric motors instead of gasoline, and they can recharge by plugging into a charging station or home outlet.
